awd_titl_txt: Experimental and theoretical investigations of gene regulation by chromosomal topological domains in E. coli
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteria are one of the simplest forms of life on Earth. Despite their relative simplicity, each single bacterial cell is still a sophisticated living system capable of precisely responding to changes in its environment. Over the last 70 years details describing of how this regulation occurs have been uncovered, however there is still gaps in our understanding. New research is uncovering evidence of a novel mechanism employed by bacterial cells to globally control the regulation of genes using the structure of chromosomal DNA. This mechanism was long thought to be missing from bacterial life forms. Investigators will explore this previously unknown regulatory mechanism using an integrated experimental and computational modeling approach. Successful completion of the project goals will contribute to the understanding of the evolution of gene regulation in bacterial systems.  As part of the broader impacts of the project, investigators will engage in interdisciplinary training of graduate students, research experience for high school students, and summer programs for elementary students within inner city communities in the Baltimore area.

The objective of the project is to investigate the role of chromosomal topological domains in regulating gene expression in E. coli. The project will combine single-cell imaging, biochemical analysis, and theoretical modeling of these topological domains to uncover their global regulatory effect on gene expression. The classic dogma of bacterial genetic information processing focuses on the regulation of a gene's transcriptional activity only through the mechanism of DNA and/or RNA sequence recognition by proteins such as RNA polymerase and transcription factors. In recent years an increasing number of studies have shown that the supercoiling state of chromosomal DNA is another fundamental factor impacting gene expression in bacteria. The topological organization of chromosomal DNA into individual domains, between which the diffusion of supercoiling is prohibited, must play an important role in gene regulation. However, knowledge of how chromosomal topological domains are organized in E. coli, and how they impact gene expression, remains elusive. In this project the two principal investigators will combine their expertise in the experimental analyses of E. coli chromosomal organization and theoretical modeling of bacterial gene regulatory networks to address three specific aims: (1) Investigate whether and how the expression of multiple genes within the same topological domain is coordinated using single cell mRNA and protein production imaging methods; (2) Model gene regulation by chromosomal topological domains at the genome scale; and (3) Determine the correlation between chromosomal topological organization and gene expression profile.  Results of the proposed work will result in the development of a topologically-informed gene regulatory network model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project is to use experimental measurements and theoretical modeling to quantify how the formation of topological domains in the bacterial chromosome influence transcription of genes. The classic bacterial gene regulation dogma depicts that a gene?s transcription activity is regulated through the recognition of specific DNA sequences by proteins such as RNA polymerase and transcription factors. In recent years an increasing number of studies has shown that the supercoiling state of chromosomal DNA is a fundamental factor impacting gene expression in bacteria. The topological organization of chromosomal DNA into individual domains, between which the diffusion of supercoiling is prohibited, thus plays an important role in gene regulation. This project investigated the hypothesis that the formation of topological domains compartmentalizes supercoiling and leads to coordinated genes expression in the same domain, which may serve as a new gene regulation mechanism (Fig. 1).

In the first line of the project, we built synthetic looping constructs to generate topologically constrained domains within the E. coli chromosome and monitored the coordination of multiple genes? expression with and without domain formation. We observed that the formation of the topological domain leads to reduced mRNA production and increased burstiness of transcription for all three genes. The mutual information (MI, a measure of the general correlation coefficient) shared between two genes showed an increase between all pairs of genes, suggesting that the topological constraint of the domain increases the correlation in these genes? expression. These results support the hypothesis that topological domain formation play important roles in regulating gene expression.

Next, we incorporated experimental measurements into a theoretical framework to model how a topological domain coordinates gene expression. We built a spatially resolved model that links transcription with the generation, propagation, and dissipation of supercoiling. The model reveals that supercoiling mediates transcription at multiple length scales, giving rise to the collective motion of co-transcribing RNA polymerase molecules, bursty mRNA production, and interactions between two adjacent genes. These result support the hypothesis that supercoiling can serve as a transcription regulator. This work is now published in PLoS Computational Biology.

In the other line of the project, we developed a method to estimate two- and three-way Mutual Information (MI) for gene expression so that new gene interactions caused by topological domains may be identified from available gene expression data. We found that a k-nearest neighbor (kNN) MI estimation method, in combination with a new inference algorithm CMIA (Conditional Mutual Information Augmentation), outperforms the current gold standard in the field. This work is now accepted for publication in BMC Bioinformatics.

Our work on this project has produced significant knowledge regarding a new type of gene regulating mechanism that is independent of transcription factor binding: the expression of multiple genes within the same topological domains could be coupled by the shared supercoiling state of the domain. Thus, the global topological organization of the chromosome impacts the coordination of gene expression beyond the typical linear operon organization. The fully integrated experimental and theoretical approach allowed a comprehensive investigation of the outstanding problem and development of new quantitative tools for future research. It complemented current in vivo genetic and in vitro biochemical studies and advanced the field of bacterial gene regulation.

Finally, the work has impacted both the broad scientific research community and the local academic community. It introduced a shift in the understanding of how gene regulation and chromosome topology interact in the prototypical organism E. coli and enabled the integration of genome-wide measurement and modeling of chromosomal DNA topology and gene expression profiles. The interdisciplinary nature of the research also provided excellent research training opportunities for five graduate students and four undergraduate students from diverse scientific and ethnic backgrounds. The principal investigators of the project also continued their community outreach activities in organizing the annual Fun with Science Summer Camp and computational biophysical research experience for underprivileged Baltimore inner city elementary school and high school students respectively.
